issue.title: CH09 Data Visualization Libraries Feedbacks
issue.body:
## matplotlib
-  ```plt.rcParams['font.sans-serif']=['SimHei']```
Some computers like mine may find no 'SimHei' font and raise a UserWarning. We can recommend the readers to try fonts like ```'Arial Unicode MS'``` if they encounter my problem. To see which fonts can be used here, I found a way from the Internet. It means the fonts with larger bytes are more likely to be Chinese fonts:
```bash
from matplotlib.font_manager import fontManager
import os
[font.name for font in fontManager.ttflist if os.path.exists(font.fname) and os.stat(font.fname).st_size>1e7]
#output: ['AppleMyungjo', 'AppleGothic', 'Arial Unicode MS']
```
## plotly
- plotly now need registration to be used. we can remind the readers to log in [here](https://plot.ly/Auth/login/#/) and regenerate an api_key after registration. We also need to add a line:
```
plotly.tools.set_credentials_file(username='XXX(you own username)', api_key='xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx(you own api_key)')
```
## pyecharts
- ```!pip install pyecharts```
When install pyecharts, someone may encounter this like me:
```error: command 'clang' failed with exit status 1```
Then I googled and learned it's because of my lack of ```xcode command tools```. The problem can be solved with operating ```!xcode-select --install``` in Jupyter. We can add this reminder.

comment.body: You are right. I should have read the Q&A. This note can also help us understand the mechanism behind this library.

issue.title: CH09 Data Visualization Libraries Feedbacks
issue.body:
## matplotlib
-  ```plt.rcParams['font.sans-serif']=['SimHei']```
Some computers like mine may find no 'SimHei' font and raise a UserWarning. We can recommend the readers to try fonts like ```'Arial Unicode MS'``` if they encounter my problem. To see which fonts can be used here, I found a way from the Internet. It means the fonts with larger bytes are more likely to be Chinese fonts:
```bash
from matplotlib.font_manager import fontManager
import os
[font.name for font in fontManager.ttflist if os.path.exists(font.fname) and os.stat(font.fname).st_size>1e7]
#output: ['AppleMyungjo', 'AppleGothic', 'Arial Unicode MS']
```
## plotly
- plotly now need registration to be used. we can remind the readers to log in [here](https://plot.ly/Auth/login/#/) and regenerate an api_key after registration. We also need to add a line:
```
plotly.tools.set_credentials_file(username='XXX(you own username)', api_key='xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx(you own api_key)')
```
## pyecharts
- ```!pip install pyecharts```
When install pyecharts, someone may encounter this like me:
```error: command 'clang' failed with exit status 1```
Then I googled and learned it's because of my lack of ```xcode command tools``` and the problem can be solved with operating ```!xcode-select --install``` in Jupyter. We can add this reminder.

issue.title: Week9_Data Viz Comments
issue.body:
Here are three quick feedback for Week 9 notes:

1. For setting up the font part, the command "!open" doesn't work on my computer. I think it is because of the Window system. But we could try the command "matplotlib.get_cachedir()" , and it works.

2. I don't know why when I set the color, it sometimes raises such ValueError:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42017792/48472352-10575300-e831-11e8-8a6e-bcc02107d8b5.png)

3. When I executed the plotly, it will return with errors like this...

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42017792/48472502-6deb9f80-e831-11e8-8687-1ec6ef4c1af5.png)

Thanks a lot if you can help me solve!

comment.body:
- For question 2, since this is a [HEXcolor](https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/网页颜色), we can only set the code from  #000000 to #ffffff.
- For question 3, we can click into the url to register and follow the instructions, then the library will work.

issue.title: How to scrape more than one page in a more efficient way
issue.body: I tried to scrape 10 pages from douban and only find this stupid way(define a function called scraper and change the url every time). But is there a better solution? I googled it and found a way to import **scrapy** but found it too difficult to understand. @ChicoXYC

comment.body:
- You've already solve the problem. You can still refer to the [job-radar](https://github.com/FLYSTEPHEN/DJ-job-radar/blob/master/job-radar.py) to make your codes more reusable. You can also give your advice to help us improve.
In this case we use 2 variables: 'page_index += step' to replace 'i = i+1', so that we can handle different websites with one series of codes. 
- BTW in @ChicoXYC 's comment, the point is to use ```open('doubanfix.csv', 'a')``` instead of ```open('doubanfix.csv', 'w')```. You can check their difference [here](https://github.com/hupili/python-for-data-and-media-communication-gitbook/blob/master/notes-week-04.md#file-operation) in our openbook. You will find that if we use 'w', the csv file will be rewritten from an empty file in every turn of a loop so that we can only get the last page's data.
